description: From Middle English facioun, from Anglo-Norman fechoun (compare Jersey Norman faichon), variant of Old French faceon, fazon, façon (“fashion, form, make, outward appearance”), from Latin factiō (“a making”), from faciō (“do, make”); see fact. Doublet of faction.

entries.meaning: (countable) A current (constantly changing) trend, favored for frivolous rather than practical, logical, or intellectual reasons.

examples: Check out the latest in fashion.

entries.meaning: (countable) A style or manner in which something is done.
The make or form of anything; the style, shape, appearance, or mode of structure; pattern, model; workmanship; execution.
examples: the fashion of the ark, of a coat, of a house, of an altar, etc.

entries.meaning: (dated) Polite, fashionable, or genteel life; social position; good breeding.

verbs.description: fashion (third-person singular simple present fashions, present participle fashioning, simple past and past participle fashioned)

entries.meaning: To make, build or construct, especially in a crude or improvised way.
examples: I have three gourds which I fill with water and take back to my cave against the long nights. I have fashioned a spear and a bow and arrow, that I may conserve my ammunition, which is running low.

entries.meaning: (dated) To make in a standard manner; to work.
examples: Fashioned plate sells for more than its weight.

entries.meaning: (dated) To fit, adapt, or accommodate to.
examples: Laws ought to be fashioned unto the manners and conditions of the people.
